title: James, the Athletic High School Coach with a Hip Fracture Mystery
clinical_history: James is a 62-year-old retired high school athletic coach who leads an active lifestyle, participating in golf every weekend and attending a yoga class twice weekly. Approximately 2 weeks ago, he tripped over an uneven pavement while jogging in his neighborhood, fell, and experienced immediate sharp pain in his left hip. He managed to get up with difficulty and limp home with assistance. Since then, he's experienced progressive pain, worsened with activities. He's noticed a significant limp, particularly painful during weight-bearing activities and has struggled to sleep due to pain.

nprs.affected_area: constant, sharp ache in the left hip

aggrevating_factors: walking more than 10 minutes, standing for over 5 minutes, climbing stairs, and attempts to jog. Getting out of bed in the morning is particularly painful.
picture: [insert image of a person highlighting the left hip region]
easing_factors: sitting in a reclined position, ibuprofen provides temporary relief, applying ice packs
past_history: Previous minor sprains during sporting activities but no significant injuries. No prior hip issues.
medical_history: Generally healthy, maintains a good exercise regimen, slightly elevated cholesterol controlled with diet.
medications: Ibuprofen 400 mg every 6 hours, as needed
personal_history: Married for 35 years with two grown children. Enjoys spending time with his grandchildren and engaging in leisure sports. Volunteers at a local sports club occasionally.
imaging: An x-ray taken at the local clinic confirmed a nondisplaced fracture of the femoral neck.
